item.title: Sydney Gunmen Were Motivated by ISIS, Australia’s Leader Says
item.description: The police found two homemade Islamic State flags in the car of the suspects, a 50-year-old man and his 24-year-old son.

item.title: What to Know About the Victims of the Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: At least 15 people were killed in the attack in Sydney, Australia, including a 10-year-old girl, a long-serving rabbi and a Holocaust survivor.

item.title: ISIS and the Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: Australian officials say the suspects were motivated by ISIS. It suggests the group may still have the ability to inspire acts of terrorism.

item.title: Australia, After a Mass Shooting During Hanukkah, Looks for a Path Forward
item.description: The Bondi Beach massacre has people fearing more anti-Jewish violence — and an Islamophobic backlash. But there are reasons to think stability will prevail.

item.title: Sydney Attackers Motivated by “Islamic State Ideology,” Officials Say
item.description: Investigators said they were also looking into a trip to the Philippines that the father-and-son attackers took last month.

item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.

item.title: Team Races Against Time to Save a Tangled Sea Lion in British Columbia
item.description: Experts tracked the sea lion, which had a rope around its neck, for over a month before they were able to catch up to it in Cowichan Bay, Canada.

item.title: Australia Doubles Down on Gun Control in Wake of Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: The country has long looked warily at the cycle of gun violence in the United States, where meaningful changes in policy have been rare.

item.title: U.S. Is Seeking Exemption From a European Climate Law, Officials Say
item.description: Diplomats told E.U. officials that the bloc’s law on methane, a potent greenhouse gas, would hurt American oil and gas companies.

item.title: India Charges Pakistan-Based Groups in April Terrorist Attack in Kashmir
item.description: India claims that Pakistan sponsored the terrorists responsible for killing 26 people in the disputed region, an accusation Pakistan denies.

item.title: US Boat Strikes Shift to Pacific, Placing Colombia on Watch
item.description: All the strikes in recent weeks have taken place in the Pacific, reflecting Colombia’s role in the drug trade and the feuding between Bogotá and Washington.

item.title: Trinidad and Tobago Sides With U.S. in Battle Against Venezuela, Military Tool Suggests
item.description: The United States and Trinidad say U.S. Marines installed a radar in Tobago to combat drugs — but this war materiel isn’t designed for operations based at sea or on land.

item.title: Man Who Plowed Car Into Liverpool F.C. Parade Is Sentenced to 21 Years
item.description: Paul Doyle was sentenced to more than 21 years on Tuesday after he struck more than 130 people leaving a victory parade for Liverpool F.C.

item.title: France Passes Welfare Budget Law, Giving Government Rare Win
item.description: Sébastien Lecornu, the third French prime minister in less than a year, succeeded where his two predecessors failed — at least for now.

item.title: Ukraine Plan Calls For Enhanced Military, With U.S. and European Backup
item.description: The latest proposal is designed to deter future Russian aggression. But Russia is not part of the talks and has shown little willingness to negotiate.

item.title: In a Remote Jungle, the Gruesome Poaching of Rare Elephants
item.description: More than a dozen Bornean elephants have been killed — including five beheaded — in Malaysia in the past 18 months, the authorities say.

item.title: Rome’s New Subway Stops Are Part Museum, Part Station
item.description: Part station, part museum, two new subway stops in Rome offer riders the chance to see ancient artifacts unearthed in digging for the stations.

item.title: Mark Carney Caught in Canada’s British Spelling Debate
item.description: Some words spelled the British way are emerging in Canadian government documents. A group of language experts say the changes undermine Canada’s identity.

item.title: Rwanda-Backed Militia Says It Will Withdraw From Key City in Congo
item.description: The militia said the withdrawal was intended to give ongoing peace talks with the Congolese government “the maximum chance to succeed.”

item.title: Zelensky Expresses Wary Optimism About Russia-Ukraine Peace Plan
item.description: Two days of talks between President Volodymyr Zelensky and allies have brought some progress on security guarantees, but Russia remains opposed to any foreign forces in Ukraine.

item.title: Dashcam Footage Shows Couple Confronting a Suspected Bondi Beach Gunman
item.description: Dash cam footage has emerged of Boris and Sofia Gurman trying to disarm one of the suspected attackers. The couple were killed, but their bravery was lauded by Australians.

item.title: 10-Year-Old Killed in Russia School Stabbing
item.description: The attack appeared to have been inspired by white supremacist ideology, Telegram channels close to intelligence agencies reported.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: The two men who killed 15 people on Sunday were driven by “Islamic State ideology,” Prime Minister Anthony Albanese told Australia’s public broadcaster.

item.title: As Israeli Settlements Get Bigger, Palestinian Hikes Grow Shorter
item.description: With Israelis rapidly building in the West Bank, Palestinian hikers are increasingly unable to walk across the land.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Hit a Submarine With Underwater Drones
item.description: As it tried to demonstrate its continuing ability to fight, Ukraine said it had used drones to inflict serious damage on a Russian Kilo-class submarine at a Black Sea port.

item.title: In Sydney Suburb Where Suspects Lived, Neighbor Saw ‘No Dramas’
item.description: He said the people in the house were relatively new to the area and largely kept to themselves.

item.title: How the Pandemic Lockdowns Changed a Songbird’s Beak
item.description: For ecologists, the Covid-19 pandemic has presented a remarkable natural experiment in what can happen to wild animals when humans stay home.

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Is a Focus of Trump’s Campaign Against Maduro
item.description: In public, the White House says it is confronting Venezuela to curb drug trafficking. Behind the scenes, gaining access to the country’s vast oil reserves is a priority.

item.title: The Next Steps for Gaza
item.description: A cease-fire is mostly holding, But tough issues remain, including the fate of Hamas weapons.

item.title: Heroic Bondi Beach Bystander’s Immigrant Background Is a Balm for Some Australians
item.description: Ahmed el Ahmed, a Muslim who arrived from Syria nearly 20 years ago, disarmed one of the suspected gunmen, who officials said were inspired by ISIS.

item.title: Brigitte Macron, First Lady of France, Says Sorry for Slur Against Feminist Activists
item.description: In a short video, the French first lady said that she was “sorry if I have hurt women victims,” but she also noted that she should be allowed to behave freely in private.

item.title: This Week Is Pivotal for Ukraine, and for Europe’s Voice in Its Future
item.description: Often left out by the United States in peace negotiations, European countries are working to assert their leadership and bolster Ukraine with an ambitious funding plan. But can they agree?

item.title: Bondi Suspects Were in Southern Philippines, Where ISIS Is Active
item.description: It remains unclear what the two men did there last month.

item.title: Hong Kong Media Tycoon Jimmy Lai’s Conviction Was Years in the Making
item.description: Jimmy Lai spent decades criticizing China’s rulers. He faces up to life in prison after a court found him guilty of national security crimes.

item.title: Here’s how Jimmy Lai became a politically outspoken tycoon.
item.description: Mr. Lai, who was found guilty on Monday in a landmark national security trial, has for decades been a rare figure in Hong Kong: A politically outspoken tycoon.

item.title: Kast’s Victory in Chile Is Another Win for Global Right-Wing Movement
item.description: José Antonio Kast, who was elected president on Sunday, is the latest conservative to rise to power promising strict law and order measures.

item.title: E.U. Flies 110 Tons of Aid to Darfur. But Will It Reach Those In Need?
item.description: The European Union has mounted an “air bridge” effort, with at least eight aid flights planned to Sudan. But getting supplies to the areas with the most dire need is an enormous challenge.

item.title: How the Bondi Beach Shooting Unfolded at a Hanukkah Celebration
item.description: Two men toting long guns opened fire on hundreds of people who were celebrating Hanukkah on Bondi Beach in Sydney, the core of the Australian city’s Jewish community.

item.title: Some Australian Jews Accuse the Government of Failing to Heed Warnings
item.description: A troubling rise in antisemitic attacks and incidents in recent years have left some feeling anger after the kind of deadly attack they felt was sure to happen.

item.title: Ukraine and Allies Agree on Security Guarantee for Peace Proposal
item.description: Crucial details on the future security of Ukraine remain unsettled as negotiators seek a deal that Russia will approve.

item.title: Albanese Vows to Toughen Gun Laws After Deadly Bondi Shooting
item.description: The police said on Monday that they expected to bring criminal charges against the surviving suspect, who is in a coma after being shot by the police.

item.title: How the Bondi Beach Community Rushed to Help Shooting Victims
item.description: I lived and worked around Bondi for years. The emergency response tells you everything you need to know about the area.

item.title: Iranian Authorities Assaulted Detained Nobel Laureate, Family Says
item.description: Narges Mohammadi and several other Iranian activists were detained last Friday. She has been beaten, requiring emergency medical treatment, and accused of working with Israel, her family said.

item.title: U.K. Spy Chief Warns of Growing Russia Threat in Europe
item.description: In her first public speech as head of MI6, Blaise Metreweli said Russia was attempting to export chaos to Europe through hybrid attacks and disinformation.

item.title: ‘Don’t Feed the Pig’: The Anti-Corruption Call That Helped Topple a Government
item.description: Mass demonstrations in Bulgaria were spurred by spreading outrage over graft that many say was fueling an authoritarian power grab.

item.title: Ahmed el Ahmed, Who Tackled One of the Bondi Beach Gunmen, Is Recovering in a Hospital
item.description: Video of Ahmed el Ahmed disarming one of the gunmen has gone viral, and officials around the world have hailed his bravery.

item.title: Australian Leaders Promise to Tighten Gun Laws After Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: The prime minister’s office said officials agreed that Australia needed “immediate” reform, including new restrictions on who is allowed to own firearms.

item.title: After Bondi Beach Attack, Australia Is Urged to Act Faster Against Antisemitism
item.description: Jillian Segal, the country’s special envoy to combat antisemitism, said the deadly incident was shocking but not surprising amid a rise in violence targeting the Jewish community.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
To China, Jimmy Lai Was an Arch Villain. To His Supporters, He Was Their Hope.
item.description: Jimmy Lai, the Hong Kong publisher and democracy campaigner, was convicted of national security charges in a city where even minor dissent is now whispered.

item.title: Louvre Museum Staff Go on Daylong Strike, Shutting Out Tourists
item.description: About a fifth of the Louvre’s 2,100 employees voted to go on strike for the day, adding to the sense of crisis at the museum since a brazen heist in October.

item.title: The Turbulent Times of Friedrich Merz
item.description: The new chancellor believes the world needs a stronger Germany. He is still navigating how to do it.

item.title: Suspects in Bondi Beach Shooting Identified as Father and Son
item.description: Officials said the father had been living in Australia since 1998, and that neither man appeared to have a criminal record before the mass shooting on Sunday.

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s Life, in Photos and Video
item.description: He attributed his rags-to-riches ascent to the freedoms of Hong Kong, and has paid a hefty price for defending them.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
Emergency Responders Recount Horror of Sydney Shooting
item.description: Two medical professionals who live near Bondi Beach, where gunmen attacked a Hanukkah festival on Sunday, described a harrowing scene.

item.title: U.S. Military Plane and JetBlue Flight Nearly Collided Over Caribbean, Radio Traffic Shows
item.description: The Air Force refueling tanker was flying without its location transponder activated and could not be detected by air traffic control.

item.title: Syrian Who Killed U.S. Soldiers Was Member of Security Forces, Officials Say
item.description: The gunman who killed two U.S. soldiers and an American civilian interpreter had been set to be dismissed from the security forces over his extremist views, U.S. and Syrian officials said.
